Message.Title: Price wars will KILL ARMH as it did AMD

Topic.Title: Price wars will KILL ARMH as it did AMD

Message.Msg: Intel also has connections with the major companies that purchase its products, such as Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL). For years, Apple bought processors from Intel for its computers, and if the company will switch sides, ARM could lose a large portion of its revenue base. ARM's advantages in pricing and power efficiency could dissipate as Intel introduces next generation chips. Intel continues to lose market share in the processors markets, it suffers from the economic slowdown in the leading economies, and it is losing costumers that trade laptops for tablets. Despite all these short term negative factors, Intel is still much bigger and has a lot more resources to allocate towards producing microprocessors than ARM has. Intel also has the connections to enter this market; therefore, it could be just a matter of time before the company starts taking market share from ARM. This process could lead to a price war, and if that happens, the company left standing is the one with the deeper pockets.

And this ARM talk of getting into the server business is a bigger joke.

Message.Title: Biggest reason ARMH server chips won't stick...
Message.Msg: ....... Intel server Chips not only don't have any problems, they are GREAT and companies love them. They aren't going to just switch to ARMH, especially since ARMH server chips aren't and won't be made by ARMH. Nobody needs those headaches when A) Intel server chips are solid and B) Intel makes said chips. Any wins ARMH gets in Server Chips will be couch money as far as Intel is concerned.

Topic.Title: Biggest reason ARMH server chips won't stick...

Message.Msg: Intel low-power server chips will be better than anything ARM has to offer by the time ARM can actually manufacture 64 bit in volume (which will be years from now). And, if that doesnt work Intel will give their chips away at cost. But, as you said, the switching costs alone will prevent any OEM to switch if there is no compelling reason to do so...there wont be. I laugh at all the Intel bear analysts who are using this ARM threat to scare investors away from Intel. What a joke.

Topic.Title: Apple

Message.Msg: Yes, I have. In the past year, over 400 million computers were sold. And these computers were desktops and laptops, most of which had Intel chips. And the sales continue to go up. I believe Intel in that worldwide PC and laptop sales will grow low double digits on average as more emerging markets get into the affordability stage. By the way, tablet sales have not been that successful. Only Apple's iPad has been successful. And I think the main reason is because it is Apple's cheapest computing product. Or should I say entertainment product since it doesn't do much computing.

Topic.Title: Apple is going to use Qualcom for I phone 5?

Message.Msg: Under the radar is SIMG Silicon Image a micro-cap supplier of chips to Samsung. Samsung selling 10 million + Galaxy S3 per month. SIMG is the big winner in Samsung's growth. View either thumbnail #51, #52 or #58 to see the Silicon Image SIMG chip in the Galaxy S3: http://www.techrepublic.com/photos/cracking-open-the-samsung-galaxy-s-iii-t-mobile/6370767?seq=58&tag=content;siu-container#photopaging Slide #58 is connected right to the USB port to support MHL (Mobile High Def Link). The same is going into smartphones throughout Asia: several in China (Huawei is one) and Taiwan (HTC is one)! SIMG reports next Tuesday; but the short SQUEEEEEZE begins now with 4 trading days remaining!

Topic.Title: 2 billion ARM chips shipped in Q2 2012

Message.Msg: They used the word "chips" in the article. My brain automatically thought of CPU. Do they have anything other than CPU? They are embedded into many devices. Smart controllers: disk, printer, refridgerators, auto, GPS, elevators, automatic doors, cash registers, parking meters, furnaces, thermostats, .... ----- The word should be (CPU) 'cores' rather than 'chips' . Yes they do other things than CPU's, they do GPU's (Mali as in the Samsung GS3) and low level physical IP.

Topic.Title: TSMC says single-customer fabs make sense

Message.Msg: We all know what that means.... TSMC, in effect, is saying that fabless semiconductor companies (and that includes all ARM-based ones) have to cough up a whole bunch of moola !!! Which they don't have because of their fairly thin margins.... Fabless companies are going to be forced to become partial-IDMs which is neither here nor there. Have to make substantial investments, however, fairly reduced integration between design and manufacturing. Great tug-of-war between TSMC/other foundries and the fabless companies!

Message.Title: Intel top today a problem
Message.Msg: Any top on current run that fails to clear 26 and stay there for a few days is a confirmation of declining tops triangle and the base at 24.8 or so gets even more stress with any selloff. Hedge if we get back up there near 26. It can also very possibly be done with it for now and go sub 25 next. This market needs to get some bs out of the system and then observe a stabilization in economy a bit later and it will rally again and get to 30 later this year. But for now we do not have a very optimistic near term stock behavior and one must be careful and prepared for a bit of pain if the base of the triangle breaks. This is why hedging near 26 is so important whenever a chance is created like today.

Topic.Title: QCOM QC VS Medfield

Message.Msg: Trends suggest that over time Intel's offerings will improve faster than ARM-based ones. The uncertainty is whether this technical edge will be enough to warrant business decisions that are influenced by several other factors. In other words will we get more of the same 2nd and 3rd tier customers gravitating towards Intel's offerings as opposed to the Apple and Samsung types. Where the needle swings to on this will determine Intel's viability in mobile and this is largely technology independent. A case in point being the south-bound ASPs at which mobile chips sell. ARM is largely isolated from this equation.

Topic.Title: TSMC says single-customer fabs make sense

Message.Msg: > but when your customers write bigger & bigger checks... When each of TSMC's customers have a market share of 100-200 million SoCs selling for $20-25 each (a billion mobile chips shared by Samsung, Qualcomm, nVidia, TI, etc.) - do they have enough market share to support writing bigger and bigger checks...? I think not... They better make sure that their checks don't bounce....or TSMC will bounce them out of their "own" fabs !

Topic.Title: QCOM QC VS Medfield

Message.Msg: How much would the price of an ARM CPU change if ARM gave away the IP free? Not much? ARM is not the competitor. The competitors are the companies who build products. As long as Intel makes reference designs available and the reference designs are respectable, the 2nd tier customers will have to think hard about not adopting. Adopting a reference design product will require less overhead and cost. A smaller engineering staff and likely less technical can take one of these designs to market. There is always new customers who can have a dramatic influence on pricing. Walmart Technology Unit for example is part of a very hungry and agressive company. Would Walmart adopt and market a Walmart phone based on an Intel reference design and how much tech resources would they need? What would happen to QCOM, AAPL, ARMH, INTC, TXN if Walmart announced a product?

Topic.Title: QCOM QC VS Medfield

Message.Msg: "ARM is not the competitor. The competitors are the companies who build products." Yes, INtel has many competitors now... not just AMD anymore... All companies have reference designs... The NVidia KAI reference design is enabling $199 Android tablets... "What would happen to QCOM, AAPL, ARMH, INTC, TXN if Walmart announced a product? While many a die hard long, Wally, Otellini, et al, clearly fail to realize (due to their absolutely faulty reliance on fundamentals) is that they likely already missed the chance they had of selling at peak margins, peak prices, peak profits back in May when it is quite likely the bear market rally ended (one can hardly call a market that failed to reach a new high a bull market, thus bear market rally, a bear market which should continue given the clearly defined pattern of lower highs and lower lows.
